subject: RE: [junit] Error on TestCase subclass in Eclipse 1.0
msgSnippet: Think that compiler is just telling you that there is no default constructor in the parent class. Try adding public TestCase(String name){ Super(name); } and
messageBody:
Think that compiler is just telling you that there is no default constructor
in the parent class.
Try adding

public TestCase(String name){
Super(name);
}

and see how you get on.

-----Original Message-----
From: Mark Tucker [mailto:mtucker@...]
Sent: 18 March 2002 16:19
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Error on TestCase subclass in Eclipse 1.0


I am using Eclipse 1.0 with JUnit, but when I create my TestCase subclass, I
get an error on that line that states:

"The constructor junit.framework.TestCase() is not visible"

I am using JUnit 3.7.

Here is my code:


package junit.samples.money;

import junit.framework.TestCase;

public class MyTestCase extends TestCase {

}


A more detailed dump of the error is:

java.lang.Error: Unresolved compilation problem:
The constructor junit.framework.TestCase() is not visible

at java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstance(Native Method)
at junit.samples.money.MyTestCase.<init>(MyTestCase.java:5)
at java.lang.Class.newInstance0(Native Method)
at java.lang.Class.newInstance(Unknown Source)
at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.getTest(RemoteTestRun
ner.java:145)
at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.getTest(RemoteTestRun
ner.java:134)
at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.runTests(RemoteTestRu
nner.java:187)
at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.run(RemoteTestRunner,
java:116)
at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.main(RemoteTestRunner
.java:68)


Thanks,

Mark
